        Text from the attached document:<span class="line"><!---->Text from the attached document:<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Vulnerability Report<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Vulnerability Report<!----></span><br>NCSC Reference: 22121437<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Reference: 22121437<!----></span><br>February 2023 (c) Crown Copyright 2023<span class="line"><!---->February 2023 (c) Crown Copyright 2023<!----></span><br><br>This information is exempt under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and may be exempt under other UK information legislation. Refer any FOIA queries to ncscinfoleg@ncsc.gov.uk<span class="line"><!---->This information is exempt under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and may be exempt under other UK information legislation. Refer any FOIA queries to ncscinfoleg@ncsc.gov.uk<!----></span><br><br>About this document<span class="line"><!---->About this document<!----></span><br>This document details a vulnerability identified by the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC). These vulnerabilities reduce the security of the application.<span class="line"><!---->This document details a vulnerability identified by the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC). These vulnerabilities reduce the security of the application.<!----></span><br><br>Bug Bounty Payment<span class="line"><!---->Bug Bounty Payment<!----></span><br>If this vulnerability is eligible for a Bug Bounty payment, we ask that the money be donated directly to NSPCC (Registered Charity Number: 216401, <span class="line"><!---->If this vulnerability is eligible for a Bug Bounty payment, we ask that the money be donated directly to NSPCC (Registered Charity Number: 216401, <!----></span>https://www.nspcc.org.uk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.nspcc.org.uk"><!---->https://www.nspcc.org.uk<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> Please contact the NCSC mailbox to inform us of the donation amount and the donation date.<span class="line"><!----> Please contact the NCSC mailbox to inform us of the donation amount and the donation date.<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Contact Information<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Contact Information<!----></span><br>The vulnerability disclosure mailbox is 'security@ncsc.gov.uk'. Please contact us for our PGP key.<span class="line"><!---->The vulnerability disclosure mailbox is 'security@ncsc.gov.uk'. Please contact us for our PGP key.<!----></span><br><br>Crediting NCSC<span class="line"><!---->Crediting NCSC<!----></span><br>NCSC would appreciate appropriate credit as 'The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)' in any advisories which you may publish about this issue.<span class="line"><!---->NCSC would appreciate appropriate credit as 'The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)' in any advisories which you may publish about this issue.<!----></span><br><br>Verification, Resolution and Release<span class="line"><!---->Verification, Resolution and Release<!----></span><br>Please inform NCSC via the 'security@ncsc.gov.uk' mailbox, quoting the NCSC Reference above, should you:<span class="line"><!---->Please inform NCSC via the 'security@ncsc.gov.uk' mailbox, quoting the NCSC Reference above, should you:<!----></span><br>- confirm that this is a security issue <span class="line"><!---->- confirm that this is a security issue <!----></span><br>- allocate the issue a CVE identifier<span class="line"><!---->- allocate the issue a CVE identifier<!----></span><br>- determine a date to release a patch <span class="line"><!---->- determine a date to release a patch <!----></span><br>- determine a date to publish advisories<span class="line"><!---->- determine a date to publish advisories<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Disclosure Policy<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Disclosure Policy<!----></span><br>NCSC has adopted the ISO 29147 approach to vulnerability disclosure and, as such, follows a coordinated disclosure approach with affected parties. We have never publicly disclosed a vulnerability prior to a fix being made available. NCSC recognises that vendors need a reasonable amount of time to mitigate a vulnerability, for example, to understand the impact to customers, to triage against other vulnerabilities, to implement a fix in coordination with others, and to make that fix available to its customers. As this will vary based on the exact situation NCSC does not define a set time frame in which a fix must be made available, and we are happy to discuss the circumstances of any particular disclosure.<span class="line"><!---->NCSC has adopted the ISO 29147 approach to vulnerability disclosure and, as such, follows a coordinated disclosure approach with affected parties. We have never publicly disclosed a vulnerability prior to a fix being made available. NCSC recognises that vendors need a reasonable amount of time to mitigate a vulnerability, for example, to understand the impact to customers, to triage against other vulnerabilities, to implement a fix in coordination with others, and to make that fix available to its customers. As this will vary based on the exact situation NCSC does not define a set time frame in which a fix must be made available, and we are happy to discuss the circumstances of any particular disclosure.<!----></span><br><br>If NCSC believes a vendor is not making appropriate progress with vulnerability resolution, we may, after discussion with the vendor, choose to share the details appropriately (for example, with service providers and our customers) to ensure that we provide appropriate mitigation of the threat to the UK and to UK interests.<span class="line"><!---->If NCSC believes a vendor is not making appropriate progress with vulnerability resolution, we may, after discussion with the vendor, choose to share the details appropriately (for example, with service providers and our customers) to ensure that we provide appropriate mitigation of the threat to the UK and to UK interests.<!----></span><br><br>Disclaimer<span class="line"><!---->Disclaimer<!----></span><br>Any NCSC findings and recommendations made have not been provided with the intention of avoiding all risks, and following the recommendations will not remove all such risk. Ownership of information risks remains with the relevant system owner at all times.<span class="line"><!---->Any NCSC findings and recommendations made have not been provided with the intention of avoiding all risks, and following the recommendations will not remove all such risk. Ownership of information risks remains with the relevant system owner at all times.<!----></span><br><br>Summary<span class="line"><!---->Summary<!----></span><br>A vulnerability has been found the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, leading to a controllable vtable call.<span class="line"><!---->A vulnerability has been found the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, leading to a controllable vtable call.<!----></span><br><br>Details<span class="line"><!---->Details<!----></span><br>Overview<span class="line"><!---->Overview<!----></span><br>A vulnerability has been found in the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, which results in an out-of-bounds read of heap memory when parsing a malicious WebM/Matroska file. The memory is used as a pointer to an object instance, on which a vtable function call is made, which would result in code execution when combined with a suitable information leak.<span class="line"><!---->A vulnerability has been found in the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, which results in an out-of-bounds read of heap memory when parsing a malicious WebM/Matroska file. The memory is used as a pointer to an object instance, on which a vtable function call is made, which would result in code execution when combined with a suitable information leak.<!----></span><br><br>While libwebm is used by a number of other media/codec libraries, such as libaom and libvpx, there appear to be limited uses for this vulnerable code path. It is possible there are other users of this library which do exercise the vulnerable code path, but further research of media applications and libraries is required.<span class="line"><!---->While libwebm is used by a number of other media/codec libraries, such as libaom and libvpx, there appear to be limited uses for this vulnerable code path. It is possible there are other users of this library which do exercise the vulnerable code path, but further research of media applications and libraries is required.<!----></span><br><br>Context<span class="line"><!---->Context<!----></span><br>WebM is a container file format for audio/video codecs which is dervied from the Matroska (MKV) file format. The MKV format is binary stream of nested Tag-Length-Values which define various elements of the file and are split up into `Clusters` and `Segments`. Each `Segment` can contain a number of `Tracks` and each `Cluster` can contain a number of `Blocks` which hold the actual video/audio data for a `Track`. Specific points of interest within a `Track` can be recorded using `CuePoints`, which define a `TrackPosition` element which references the ID of the `Block` within the `Track` to seek to.Libwebm implements a number of classes to handle parsing of each supported element, of interest is the `CuePoint::TrackPosition` parser:<span class="line"><!---->WebM is a container file format for audio/video codecs which is dervied from the Matroska (MKV) file format. The MKV format is binary stream of nested Tag-Length-Values which define various elements of the file and are split up into `Clusters` and `Segments`. Each `Segment` can contain a number of `Tracks` and each `Cluster` can contain a number of `Blocks` which hold the actual video/audio data for a `Track`. Specific points of interest within a `Track` can be recorded using `CuePoints`, which define a `TrackPosition` element which references the ID of the `Block` within the `Track` to seek to.Libwebm implements a number of classes to handle parsing of each supported element, of interest is the `CuePoint::TrackPosition` parser:<!----></span><br><br>bool CuePoint::TrackPosition::Parse(IMkvReader* pReader, long long start_,<span class="line"><!---->bool CuePoint::TrackPosition::Parse(IMkvReader* pReader, long long start_,<!----></span><br>                                    long long size_) {<span class="line"><!---->                                    long long size_) {<!----></span><br>  const long long stop = start_ + size_;<span class="line"><!---->  const long long stop = start_ + size_;<!----></span><br>  long long pos = start_;<span class="line"><!---->  long long pos = start_;<!----></span><br>  m_track = -1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_track = -1;<!----></span><br>  m_pos = -1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_pos = -1;<!----></span><br>  m_block = 1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_block = 1;<!----></span><br><br>  // default<span class="line"><!---->  // default<!----></span><br>  while (pos < stop) {<span class="line"><!---->  while (pos &lt; stop) {<!----></span><br>    long len;<span class="line"><!---->    long len;<!----></span><br>    const long long id = ReadID(pReader, pos, len);<span class="line"><!---->    const long long id = ReadID(pReader, pos, len);<!----></span><br>    if ((id < 0) || ((pos + len) > stop)) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((id &lt; 0) || ((pos + len) &gt; stop)) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }      <span class="line"><!---->    }      <!----></span><br>    pos += len; // consume ID[1]<span class="line"><!---->    pos += len; // consume ID[1]<!----></span><br>    const long long size = ReadUInt(pReader, pos, len);<span class="line"><!---->    const long long size = ReadUInt(pReader, pos, len);<!----></span><br>    if ((size < 0) || ((pos + len) > stop)) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((size &lt; 0) || ((pos + len) &gt; stop)) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    pos += len; // consume Size field<span class="line"><!---->    pos += len; // consume Size field<!----></span><br>    if ((pos + size) > stop) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((pos + size) &gt; stop) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }      <span class="line"><!---->    }      <!----></span><br>    if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueTrack)<span class="line"><!---->    if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueTrack)<!----></span><br>      m_track = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_track = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueClusterPosition)<span class="line"><!---->    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueClusterPosition)<!----></span><br>      m_pos = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_pos = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueBlockNumber)[2]<span class="line"><!---->    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueBlockNumber)[2]<!----></span><br>      m_block = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_block = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    pos += size; // consume payload <span class="line"><!---->    pos += size; // consume payload <!----></span><br>  } //[3] <span class="line"><!---->  } //[3] <!----></span><br>  if ((m_pos < 0) || (m_track <= 0)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if ((m_pos &lt; 0) || (m_track &lt;= 0)) {<!----></span><br>    return false;<span class="line"><!---->    return false;<!----></span><br>  }    <span class="line"><!---->  }    <!----></span><br>  return true;<span class="line"><!---->  return true;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>The TLV for the `TrackPosition` section can container three values: the ID of the `Track`, the position within the `Cluster` for the `Track` and the Block ID within the `Cluster`. These values are also TLVs and the length for each is read at [1]. The MKV format supports reading numerical values up to 8 bytes in length and the function stores these in a `long long` where `-1` indicates an error. The ID for the `Block` is read at [2] but is excluded from the bounds check at [3], allowing an arbitrary 64-bit value to be read in to `m_block`.<span class="line"><!---->The TLV for the `TrackPosition` section can container three values: the ID of the `Track`, the position within the `Cluster` for the `Track` and the Block ID within the `Cluster`. These values are also TLVs and the length for each is read at [1]. The MKV format supports reading numerical values up to 8 bytes in length and the function stores these in a `long long` where `-1` indicates an error. The ID for the `Block` is read at [2] but is excluded from the bounds check at [3], allowing an arbitrary 64-bit value to be read in to `m_block`.<!----></span><br>This is an issue when users of libwebm attempt to fetch the Block for a `TrackPosition` via the `Cluster::GetEntry` API:<span class="line"><!---->This is an issue when users of libwebm attempt to fetch the Block for a `TrackPosition` via the `Cluster::GetEntry` API:<!----></span><br><br>const BlockEntry* Cluster::GetEntry(const CuePoint& cp,<span class="line"><!---->const BlockEntry* Cluster::GetEntry(const CuePoint&amp; cp,<!----></span><br>                                    const CuePoint::TrackPosition& tp) const {<span class="line"><!---->                                    const CuePoint::TrackPosition&amp; tp) const {<!----></span><br>  const long long tc = cp.GetTimeCode(); //[4] <span class="line"><!---->  const long long tc = cp.GetTimeCode(); //[4] <!----></span><br>  if (tp.m_block < 0) { //[5]   <span class="line"><!---->  if (tp.m_block &lt; 0) { //[5]   <!----></span><br>    const long block = static_cast<long>(tp.m_block);<span class="line"><!---->    const long block = static_cast&lt;long&gt;(tp.m_block);<!----></span><br>    const long index = block - 1; //[6]<span class="line"><!---->    const long index = block - 1; //[6]<!----></span><br>    while (index >= m_entries_count) {<span class="line"><!---->    while (index &gt;= m_entries_count) {<!----></span><br>      long long pos;<span class="line"><!---->      long long pos;<!----></span><br>      long len;<span class="line"><!---->      long len;<!----></span><br>      const long status = Parse(pos, len);        <span class="line"><!---->      const long status = Parse(pos, len);        <!----></span><br>      if (status < 0)  <span class="line"><!---->      if (status &lt; 0)  <!----></span><br>        // TODO: can this happen?          <span class="line"><!---->        // TODO: can this happen?          <!----></span><br>        return NULL;        <span class="line"><!---->        return NULL;        <!----></span><br>      if (status > 0) <span class="line"><!---->      if (status &gt; 0) <!----></span><br>        // nothing remains to be parsed          <span class="line"><!---->        // nothing remains to be parsed          <!----></span><br>        return NULL;<span class="line"><!---->        return NULL;<!----></span><br>      } //[7]   <span class="line"><!---->      } //[7]   <!----></span><br>      const BlockEntry* const pEntry = m_entries[index]; //[8]   <span class="line"><!---->      const BlockEntry* const pEntry = m_entries[index]; //[8]   <!----></span><br>      const Block* const pBlock = pEntry->GetBlock();        <span class="line"><!---->      const Block* const pBlock = pEntry-&gt;GetBlock();        <!----></span><br>      if ((pBlock->GetTrackNumber() == tp.m_track) &&<span class="line"><!---->      if ((pBlock-&gt;GetTrackNumber() == tp.m_track) &amp;&amp;<!----></span><br>          (pBlock->GetTimeCode(this) == tc)) {<span class="line"><!---->          (pBlock-&gt;GetTimeCode(this) == tc)) {<!----></span><br>        return pEntry;      <span class="line"><!---->        return pEntry;      <!----></span><br>      }    <span class="line"><!---->      }    <!----></span><br>    }    <span class="line"><!---->    }    <!----></span><br>    // ...<span class="line"><!---->    // ...<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  At [4] a check is made that the 64-bit `long long` block ID in `m_block` is greater than zero, which is then downcast to a 32-bit `long` at [5]. As an arbitrary 64-bit value can be read in from the TLV, a positive 64-bit value can be truncated to a negative 32-bit value and stored in the `block` variable. As `block` is now negative, the loop at [6] can be skipped. At [7] the negative 32-bit value is then used as an index into the `m_entries` array of `BlockEntry`'s which will read out-of-bounds, resulting in an invalid `BlockEntry*`. At [8] this will result in a vtable being read from the invalid pointer and a call made to one of its functions.<span class="line"><!---->  At [4] a check is made that the 64-bit `long long` block ID in `m_block` is greater than zero, which is then downcast to a 32-bit `long` at [5]. As an arbitrary 64-bit value can be read in from the TLV, a positive 64-bit value can be truncated to a negative 32-bit value and stored in the `block` variable. As `block` is now negative, the loop at [6] can be skipped. At [7] the negative 32-bit value is then used as an index into the `m_entries` array of `BlockEntry`'s which will read out-of-bounds, resulting in an invalid `BlockEntry*`. At [8] this will result in a vtable being read from the invalid pointer and a call made to one of its functions.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  Exploitation<span class="line"><!---->  Exploitation<!----></span><br>  It is likely that a separate information leak would be required to exploit this vulnerability. With an information leak it should be possible to groom the heap during file parsing such that the invalid `BlockEntry*` points at user-controllable memory containing a fake vtable in order to gain initial RCE. As MKV `Cluster`'s can contain `Block`'s with a relatively arbitrary size containing arbitrary binary data, they would make a useful primitive for the heap groom. The Block ID can be an arbitrary negative 32-bit value as well, which allows for a lot of flexibility in positioning memory to use as the fake `BlockEntry`.<span class="line"><!---->  It is likely that a separate information leak would be required to exploit this vulnerability. With an information leak it should be possible to groom the heap during file parsing such that the invalid `BlockEntry*` points at user-controllable memory containing a fake vtable in order to gain initial RCE. As MKV `Cluster`'s can contain `Block`'s with a relatively arbitrary size containing arbitrary binary data, they would make a useful primitive for the heap groom. The Block ID can be an arbitrary negative 32-bit value as well, which allows for a lot of flexibility in positioning memory to use as the fake `BlockEntry`.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  A C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path is included with this report.<span class="line"><!---->  A C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path is included with this report.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  Proof Of Concept<span class="line"><!---->  Proof Of Concept<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path<span class="line"><!---->  C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  #include <Windows.h><span class="line"><!---->  #include &lt;Windows.h&gt;<!----></span><br>  #include <stdio.h><span class="line"><!---->  #include &lt;stdio.h&gt;<!----></span><br>  #include "mkvparser/mkvparser.h"<span class="line"><!---->  #include "mkvparser/mkvparser.h"<!----></span><br>  #include "mkvparser/mkvreader.h"<span class="line"><!---->  #include "mkvparser/mkvreader.h"<!----></span><br>  using namespace mkvparser;<span class="line"><!---->  using namespace mkvparser;<!----></span><br>  int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {  <span class="line"><!---->  int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {  <!----></span><br>    MkvReader* reader = NULL; <span class="line"><!---->    MkvReader* reader = NULL; <!----></span><br>    const char* path = "poc.webm";  <span class="line"><!---->    const char* path = "poc.webm";  <!----></span><br>    do {<span class="line"><!---->    do {<!----></span><br>      reader = new MkvReader();<span class="line"><!---->      reader = new MkvReader();<!----></span><br>      if (reader->Open(path) < 0) {<span class="line"><!---->      if (reader-&gt;Open(path) &lt; 0) {<!----></span><br>        printf("MkvReader::Open failed\r\n");<span class="line"><!---->        printf("MkvReader::Open failed\r\n");<!----></span><br>        break;<span class="line"><!---->        break;<!----></span><br>      }<span class="line"><!---->      }<!----></span><br>      // Code example referencing <span class="line"><!---->      // Code example referencing <!----></span><br>      // libaom\source\libaom\common\webmdec.cc: file_is_webmlong <span class="line"><!---->      // libaom\source\libaom\common\webmdec.cc: file_is_webmlong <!----></span><br>      long pos = 0;<span         for LitElement.

        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;

        for LitElement.

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      <style>
        mr-issue-details {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background-color: var(--chops-white);
          padding-bottom: 1em;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;

        }
        h3 {
          margin-top: 1em;
        }
        mr-description {
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        mr-edit-issue {
          margin-top: 40px;
        }
      </style>

        Text from the attached document:<span class="line"><!---->Text from the attached document:<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Vulnerability Report<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Vulnerability Report<!----></span><br>NCSC Reference: 22121437<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Reference: 22121437<!----></span><br>February 2023 (c) Crown Copyright 2023<span class="line"><!---->February 2023 (c) Crown Copyright 2023<!----></span><br><br>This information is exempt under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and may be exempt under other UK information legislation. Refer any FOIA queries to ncscinfoleg@ncsc.gov.uk<span class="line"><!---->This information is exempt under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and may be exempt under other UK information legislation. Refer any FOIA queries to ncscinfoleg@ncsc.gov.uk<!----></span><br><br>About this document<span class="line"><!---->About this document<!----></span><br>This document details a vulnerability identified by the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC). These vulnerabilities reduce the security of the application.<span class="line"><!---->This document details a vulnerability identified by the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC). These vulnerabilities reduce the security of the application.<!----></span><br><br>Bug Bounty Payment<span class="line"><!---->Bug Bounty Payment<!----></span><br>If this vulnerability is eligible for a Bug Bounty payment, we ask that the money be donated directly to NSPCC (Registered Charity Number: 216401, <span class="line"><!---->If this vulnerability is eligible for a Bug Bounty payment, we ask that the money be donated directly to NSPCC (Registered Charity Number: 216401, <!----></span>https://www.nspcc.org.uk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.nspcc.org.uk"><!---->https://www.nspcc.org.uk<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> Please contact the NCSC mailbox to inform us of the donation amount and the donation date.<span class="line"><!----> Please contact the NCSC mailbox to inform us of the donation amount and the donation date.<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Contact Information<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Contact Information<!----></span><br>The vulnerability disclosure mailbox is 'security@ncsc.gov.uk'. Please contact us for our PGP key.<span class="line"><!---->The vulnerability disclosure mailbox is 'security@ncsc.gov.uk'. Please contact us for our PGP key.<!----></span><br><br>Crediting NCSC<span class="line"><!---->Crediting NCSC<!----></span><br>NCSC would appreciate appropriate credit as 'The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)' in any advisories which you may publish about this issue.<span class="line"><!---->NCSC would appreciate appropriate credit as 'The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)' in any advisories which you may publish about this issue.<!----></span><br><br>Verification, Resolution and Release<span class="line"><!---->Verification, Resolution and Release<!----></span><br>Please inform NCSC via the 'security@ncsc.gov.uk' mailbox, quoting the NCSC Reference above, should you:<span class="line"><!---->Please inform NCSC via the 'security@ncsc.gov.uk' mailbox, quoting the NCSC Reference above, should you:<!----></span><br>- confirm that this is a security issue <span class="line"><!---->- confirm that this is a security issue <!----></span><br>- allocate the issue a CVE identifier<span class="line"><!---->- allocate the issue a CVE identifier<!----></span><br>- determine a date to release a patch <span class="line"><!---->- determine a date to release a patch <!----></span><br>- determine a date to publish advisories<span class="line"><!---->- determine a date to publish advisories<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Disclosure Policy<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Disclosure Policy<!----></span><br>NCSC has adopted the ISO 29147 approach to vulnerability disclosure and, as such, follows a coordinated disclosure approach with affected parties. We have never publicly disclosed a vulnerability prior to a fix being made available. NCSC recognises that vendors need a reasonable amount of time to mitigate a vulnerability, for example, to understand the impact to customers, to triage against other vulnerabilities, to implement a fix in coordination with others, and to make that fix available to its customers. As this will vary based on the exact situation NCSC does not define a set time frame in which a fix must be made available, and we are happy to discuss the circumstances of any particular disclosure.<span class="line"><!---->NCSC has adopted the ISO 29147 approach to vulnerability disclosure and, as such, follows a coordinated disclosure approach with affected parties. We have never publicly disclosed a vulnerability prior to a fix being made available. NCSC recognises that vendors need a reasonable amount of time to mitigate a vulnerability, for example, to understand the impact to customers, to triage against other vulnerabilities, to implement a fix in coordination with others, and to make that fix available to its customers. As this will vary based on the exact situation NCSC does not define a set time frame in which a fix must be made available, and we are happy to discuss the circumstances of any particular disclosure.<!----></span><br><br>If NCSC believes a vendor is not making appropriate progress with vulnerability resolution, we may, after discussion with the vendor, choose to share the details appropriately (for example, with service providers and our customers) to ensure that we provide appropriate mitigation of the threat to the UK and to UK interests.<span class="line"><!---->If NCSC believes a vendor is not making appropriate progress with vulnerability resolution, we may, after discussion with the vendor, choose to share the details appropriately (for example, with service providers and our customers) to ensure that we provide appropriate mitigation of the threat to the UK and to UK interests.<!----></span><br><br>Disclaimer<span class="line"><!---->Disclaimer<!----></span><br>Any NCSC findings and recommendations made have not been provided with the intention of avoiding all risks, and following the recommendations will not remove all such risk. Ownership of information risks remains with the relevant system owner at all times.<span class="line"><!---->Any NCSC findings and recommendations made have not been provided with the intention of avoiding all risks, and following the recommendations will not remove all such risk. Ownership of information risks remains with the relevant system owner at all times.<!----></span><br><br>Summary<span class="line"><!---->Summary<!----></span><br>A vulnerability has been found the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, leading to a controllable vtable call.<span class="line"><!---->A vulnerability has been found the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, leading to a controllable vtable call.<!----></span><br><br>Details<span class="line"><!---->Details<!----></span><br>Overview<span class="line"><!---->Overview<!----></span><br>A vulnerability has been found in the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, which results in an out-of-bounds read of heap memory when parsing a malicious WebM/Matroska file. The memory is used as a pointer to an object instance, on which a vtable function call is made, which would result in code execution when combined with a suitable information leak.<span class="line"><!---->A vulnerability has been found in the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, which results in an out-of-bounds read of heap memory when parsing a malicious WebM/Matroska file. The memory is used as a pointer to an object instance, on which a vtable function call is made, which would result in code execution when combined with a suitable information leak.<!----></span><br><br>While libwebm is used by a number of other media/codec libraries, such as libaom and libvpx, there appear to be limited uses for this vulnerable code path. It is possible there are other users of this library which do exercise the vulnerable code path, but further research of media applications and libraries is required.<span class="line"><!---->While libwebm is used by a number of other media/codec libraries, such as libaom and libvpx, there appear to be limited uses for this vulnerable code path. It is possible there are other users of this library which do exercise the vulnerable code path, but further research of media applications and libraries is required.<!----></span><br><br>Context<span class="line"><!---->Context<!----></span><br>WebM is a container file format for audio/video codecs which is dervied from the Matroska (MKV) file format. The MKV format is binary stream of nested Tag-Length-Values which define various elements of the file and are split up into `Clusters` and `Segments`. Each `Segment` can contain a number of `Tracks` and each `Cluster` can contain a number of `Blocks` which hold the actual video/audio data for a `Track`. Specific points of interest within a `Track` can be recorded using `CuePoints`, which define a `TrackPosition` element which references the ID of the `Block` within the `Track` to seek to.Libwebm implements a number of classes to handle parsing of each supported element, of interest is the `CuePoint::TrackPosition` parser:<span class="line"><!---->WebM is a container file format for audio/video codecs which is dervied from the Matroska (MKV) file format. The MKV format is binary stream of nested Tag-Length-Values which define various elements of the file and are split up into `Clusters` and `Segments`. Each `Segment` can contain a number of `Tracks` and each `Cluster` can contain a number of `Blocks` which hold the actual video/audio data for a `Track`. Specific points of interest within a `Track` can be recorded using `CuePoints`, which define a `TrackPosition` element which references the ID of the `Block` within the `Track` to seek to.Libwebm implements a number of classes to handle parsing of each supported element, of interest is the `CuePoint::TrackPosition` parser:<!----></span><br><br>bool CuePoint::TrackPosition::Parse(IMkvReader* pReader, long long start_,<span class="line"><!---->bool CuePoint::TrackPosition::Parse(IMkvReader* pReader, long long start_,<!----></span><br>                                    long long size_) {<span class="line"><!---->                                    long long size_) {<!----></span><br>  const long long stop = start_ + size_;<span class="line"><!---->  const long long stop = start_ + size_;<!----></span><br>  long long pos = start_;<span class="line"><!---->  long long pos = start_;<!----></span><br>  m_track = -1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_track = -1;<!----></span><br>  m_pos = -1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_pos = -1;<!----></span><br>  m_block = 1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_block = 1;<!----></span><br><br>  // default<span class="line"><!---->  // default<!----></span><br>  while (pos < stop) {<span class="line"><!---->  while (pos &lt; stop) {<!----></span><br>    long len;<span class="line"><!---->    long len;<!----></span><br>    const long long id = ReadID(pReader, pos, len);<span class="line"><!---->    const long long id = ReadID(pReader, pos, len);<!----></span><br>    if ((id < 0) || ((pos + len) > stop)) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((id &lt; 0) || ((pos + len) &gt; stop)) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }      <span class="line"><!---->    }      <!----></span><br>    pos += len; // consume ID[1]<span class="line"><!---->    pos += len; // consume ID[1]<!----></span><br>    const long long size = ReadUInt(pReader, pos, len);<span class="line"><!---->    const long long size = ReadUInt(pReader, pos, len);<!----></span><br>    if ((size < 0) || ((pos + len) > stop)) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((size &lt; 0) || ((pos + len) &gt; stop)) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    pos += len; // consume Size field<span class="line"><!---->    pos += len; // consume Size field<!----></span><br>    if ((pos + size) > stop) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((pos + size) &gt; stop) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }      <span class="line"><!---->    }      <!----></span><br>    if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueTrack)<span class="line"><!---->    if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueTrack)<!----></span><br>      m_track = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_track = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueClusterPosition)<span class="line"><!---->    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueClusterPosition)<!----></span><br>      m_pos = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_pos = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueBlockNumber)[2]<span class="line"><!---->    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueBlockNumber)[2]<!----></span><br>      m_block = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_block = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    pos += size; // consume payload <span class="line"><!---->    pos += size; // consume payload <!----></span><br>  } //[3] <span class="line"><!---->  } //[3] <!----></span><br>  if ((m_pos < 0) || (m_track <= 0)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if ((m_pos &lt; 0) || (m_track &lt;= 0)) {<!----></span><br>    return false;<span class="line"><!---->    return false;<!----></span><br>  }    <span class="line"><!---->  }    <!----></span><br>  return true;<span class="line"><!---->  return true;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>The TLV for the `TrackPosition` section can container three values: the ID of the `Track`, the position within the `Cluster` for the `Track` and the Block ID within the `Cluster`. These values are also TLVs and the length for each is read at [1]. The MKV format supports reading numerical values up to 8 bytes in length and the function stores these in a `long long` where `-1` indicates an error. The ID for the `Block` is read at [2] but is excluded from the bounds check at [3], allowing an arbitrary 64-bit value to be read in to `m_block`.<span class="line"><!---->The TLV for the `TrackPosition` section can container three values: the ID of the `Track`, the position within the `Cluster` for the `Track` and the Block ID within the `Cluster`. These values are also TLVs and the length for each is read at [1]. The MKV format supports reading numerical values up to 8 bytes in length and the function stores these in a `long long` where `-1` indicates an error. The ID for the `Block` is read at [2] but is excluded from the bounds check at [3], allowing an arbitrary 64-bit value to be read in to `m_block`.<!----></span><br>This is an issue when users of libwebm attempt to fetch the Block for a `TrackPosition` via the `Cluster::GetEntry` API:<span class="line"><!---->This is an issue when users of libwebm attempt to fetch the Block for a `TrackPosition` via the `Cluster::GetEntry` API:<!----></span><br><br>const BlockEntry* Cluster::GetEntry(const CuePoint& cp,<span class="line"><!---->const BlockEntry* Cluster::GetEntry(const CuePoint&amp; cp,<!----></span><br>                                    const CuePoint::TrackPosition& tp) const {<span class="line"><!---->                                    const CuePoint::TrackPosition&amp; tp) const {<!----></span><br>  const long long tc = cp.GetTimeCode(); //[4] <span class="line"><!---->  const long long tc = cp.GetTimeCode(); //[4] <!----></span><br>  if (tp.m_block < 0) { //[5]   <span class="line"><!---->  if (tp.m_block &lt; 0) { //[5]   <!----></span><br>    const long block = static_cast<long>(tp.m_block);<span class="line"><!---->    const long block = static_cast&lt;long&gt;(tp.m_block);<!----></span><br>    const long index = block - 1; //[6]<span class="line"><!---->    const long index = block - 1; //[6]<!----></span><br>    while (index >= m_entries_count) {<span class="line"><!---->    while (index &gt;= m_entries_count) {<!----></span><br>      long long pos;<span class="line"><!---->      long long pos;<!----></span><br>      long len;<span class="line"><!---->      long len;<!----></span><br>      const long status = Parse(pos, len);        <span class="line"><!---->      const long status = Parse(pos, len);        <!----></span><br>      if (status < 0)  <span class="line"><!---->      if (status &lt; 0)  <!----></span><br>        // TODO: can this happen?          <span class="line"><!---->        // TODO: can this happen?          <!----></span><br>        return NULL;        <span class="line"><!---->        return NULL;        <!----></span><br>      if (status > 0) <span class="line"><!---->      if (status &gt; 0) <!----></span><br>        // nothing remains to be parsed          <span class="line"><!---->        // nothing remains to be parsed          <!----></span><br>        return NULL;<span class="line"><!---->        return NULL;<!----></span><br>      } //[7]   <span class="line"><!---->      } //[7]   <!----></span><br>      const BlockEntry* const pEntry = m_entries[index]; //[8]   <span class="line"><!---->      const BlockEntry* const pEntry = m_entries[index]; //[8]   <!----></span><br>      const Block* const pBlock = pEntry->GetBlock();        <span class="line"><!---->      const Block* const pBlock = pEntry-&gt;GetBlock();        <!----></span><br>      if ((pBlock->GetTrackNumber() == tp.m_track) &&<span class="line"><!---->      if ((pBlock-&gt;GetTrackNumber() == tp.m_track) &amp;&amp;<!----></span><br>          (pBlock->GetTimeCode(this) == tc)) {<span class="line"><!---->          (pBlock-&gt;GetTimeCode(this) == tc)) {<!----></span><br>        return pEntry;      <span class="line"><!---->        return pEntry;      <!----></span><br>      }    <span class="line"><!---->      }    <!----></span><br>    }    <span class="line"><!---->    }    <!----></span><br>    // ...<span class="line"><!---->    // ...<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  At [4] a check is made that the 64-bit `long long` block ID in `m_block` is greater than zero, which is then downcast to a 32-bit `long` at [5]. As an arbitrary 64-bit value can be read in from the TLV, a positive 64-bit value can be truncated to a negative 32-bit value and stored in the `block` variable. As `block` is now negative, the loop at [6] can be skipped. At [7] the negative 32-bit value is then used as an index into the `m_entries` array of `BlockEntry`'s which will read out-of-bounds, resulting in an invalid `BlockEntry*`. At [8] this will result in a vtable being read from the invalid pointer and a call made to one of its functions.<span class="line"><!---->  At [4] a check is made that the 64-bit `long long` block ID in `m_block` is greater than zero, which is then downcast to a 32-bit `long` at [5]. As an arbitrary 64-bit value can be read in from the TLV, a positive 64-bit value can be truncated to a negative 32-bit value and stored in the `block` variable. As `block` is now negative, the loop at [6] can be skipped. At [7] the negative 32-bit value is then used as an index into the `m_entries` array of `BlockEntry`'s which will read out-of-bounds, resulting in an invalid `BlockEntry*`. At [8] this will result in a vtable being read from the invalid pointer and a call made to one of its functions.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  Exploitation<span class="line"><!---->  Exploitation<!----></span><br>  It is likely that a separate information leak would be required to exploit this vulnerability. With an information leak it should be possible to groom the heap during file parsing such that the invalid `BlockEntry*` points at user-controllable memory containing a fake vtable in order to gain initial RCE. As MKV `Cluster`'s can contain `Block`'s with a relatively arbitrary size containing arbitrary binary data, they would make a useful primitive for the heap groom. The Block ID can be an arbitrary negative 32-bit value as well, which allows for a lot of flexibility in positioning memory to use as the fake `BlockEntry`.<span class="line"><!---->  It is likely that a separate information leak would be required to exploit this vulnerability. With an information leak it should be possible to groom the heap during file parsing such that the invalid `BlockEntry*` points at user-controllable memory containing a fake vtable in order to gain initial RCE. As MKV `Cluster`'s can contain `Block`'s with a relatively arbitrary size containing arbitrary binary data, they would make a useful primitive for the heap groom. The Block ID can be an arbitrary negative 32-bit value as well, which allows for a lot of flexibility in positioning memory to use as the fake `BlockEntry`.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  A C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path is included with this report.<span class="line"><!---->  A C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path is included with this report.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  Proof Of Concept<span class="line"><!---->  Proof Of Concept<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path<span class="line"><!---->  C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  #include <Windows.h><span class="line"><!---->  #include &lt;Windows.h&gt;<!----></span><br>  #include <stdio.h><span class="line"><!---->  #include cluster = segment->GetFirst();<span class="line"><!---->      const Cluster* cluster = segment-&gt;GetFirst();<!----></span><br>      if (!cluster) {<span class="line"><!---->      if (!cluster)         Text from the attached document:<span class="line"><!---->Text from the attached document:<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Vulnerability Report<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Vulnerability Report<!----></span><br>NCSC Reference: 22121437<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Reference: 22121437<!----></span><br>February 2023 (c) Crown Copyright 2023<span class="line"><!---->February 2023 (c) Crown Copyright 2023<!----></span><br><br>This information is exempt under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and may be exempt under other UK information legislation. Refer any FOIA queries to ncscinfoleg@ncsc.gov.uk<span class="line"><!---->This information is exempt under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 (FOIA) and may be exempt under other UK information legislation. Refer any FOIA queries to ncscinfoleg@ncsc.gov.uk<!----></span><br><br>About this document<span class="line"><!---->About this document<!----></span><br>This document details a vulnerability identified by the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC). These vulnerabilities reduce the security of the application.<span class="line"><!---->This document details a vulnerability identified by the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC). These vulnerabilities reduce the security of the application.<!----></span><br><br>Bug Bounty Payment<span class="line"><!---->Bug Bounty Payment<!----></span><br>If this vulnerability is eligible for a Bug Bounty payment, we ask that the money be donated directly to NSPCC (Registered Charity Number: 216401, <span class="line"><!---->If this vulnerability is eligible for a Bug Bounty payment, we ask that the money be donated directly to NSPCC (Registered Charity Number: 216401, <!----></span>https://www.nspcc.org.uk<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.nspcc.org.uk"><!---->https://www.nspcc.org.uk<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> Please contact the NCSC mailbox to inform us of the donation amount and the donation date.<span class="line"><!----> Please contact the NCSC mailbox to inform us of the donation amount and the donation date.<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Contact Information<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Contact Information<!----></span><br>The vulnerability disclosure mailbox is 'security@ncsc.gov.uk'. Please contact us for our PGP key.<span class="line"><!---->The vulnerability disclosure mailbox is 'security@ncsc.gov.uk'. Please contact us for our PGP key.<!----></span><br><br>Crediting NCSC<span class="line"><!---->Crediting NCSC<!----></span><br>NCSC would appreciate appropriate credit as 'The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)' in any advisories which you may publish about this issue.<span class="line"><!---->NCSC would appreciate appropriate credit as 'The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)' in any advisories which you may publish about this issue.<!----></span><br><br>Verification, Resolution and Release<span class="line"><!---->Verification, Resolution and Release<!----></span><br>Please inform NCSC via the 'security@ncsc.gov.uk' mailbox, quoting the NCSC Reference above, should you:<span class="line"><!---->Please inform NCSC via the 'security@ncsc.gov.uk' mailbox, quoting the NCSC Reference above, should you:<!----></span><br>- confirm that this is a security issue <span class="line"><!---->- confirm that this is a security issue <!----></span><br>- allocate the issue a CVE identifier<span class="line"><!---->- allocate the issue a CVE identifier<!----></span><br>- determine a date to release a patch <span class="line"><!---->- determine a date to release a patch <!----></span><br>- determine a date to publish advisories<span class="line"><!---->- determine a date to publish advisories<!----></span><br><br>NCSC Disclosure Policy<span class="line"><!---->NCSC Disclosure Policy<!----></span><br>NCSC has adopted the ISO 29147 approach to vulnerability disclosure and, as such, follows a coordinated disclosure approach with affected parties. We have never publicly disclosed a vulnerability prior to a fix being made available. NCSC recognises that vendors need a reasonable amount of time to mitigate a vulnerability, for example, to understand the impact to customers, to triage against other vulnerabilities, to implement a fix in coordination with others, and to make that fix available to its customers. As this will vary based on the exact situation NCSC does not define a set time frame in which a fix must be made available, and we are happy to discuss the circumstances of any particular disclosure.<span class="line"><!---->NCSC has adopted the ISO 29147 approach to vulnerability disclosure and, as such, follows a coordinated disclosure approach with affected parties. We have never publicly disclosed a vulnerability prior to a fix being made available. NCSC recognises that vendors need a reasonable amount of time to mitigate a vulnerability, for example, to understand the impact to customers, to triage against other vulnerabilities, to implement a fix in coordination with others, and to make that fix available to its customers. As this will vary based on the exact situation NCSC does not define a set time frame in which a fix must be made available, and we are happy to discuss the circumstances of any particular disclosure.<!----></span><br><br>If NCSC believes a vendor is not making appropriate progress with vulnerability resolution, we may, after discussion with the vendor, choose to share the details appropriately (for example, with service providers and our customers) to ensure that we provide appropriate mitigation of the threat to the UK and to UK interests.<span class="line"><!---->If NCSC believes a vendor is not making appropriate progress with vulnerability resolution, we may, after discussion with the vendor, choose to share the details appropriately (for example, with service providers and our customers) to ensure that we provide appropriate mitigation of the threat to the UK and to UK interests.<!----></span><br><br>Disclaimer<span class="line"><!---->Disclaimer<!----></span><br>Any NCSC findings and recommendations made have not been provided with the intention of avoiding all risks, and following the recommendations will not remove all such risk. Ownership of information risks remains with the relevant system owner at all times.<span class="line"><!---->Any NCSC findings and recommendations made have not been provided with the intention of avoiding all risks, and following the recommendations will not remove all such risk. Ownership of information risks remains with the relevant system owner at all times.<!----></span><br><br>Summary<span class="line"><!---->Summary<!----></span><br>A vulnerability has been found the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, leading to a controllable vtable call.<span class="line"><!---->A vulnerability has been found the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, leading to a controllable vtable call.<!----></span><br><br>Details<span class="line"><!---->Details<!----></span><br>Overview<span class="line"><!---->Overview<!----></span><br>A vulnerability has been found in the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, which results in an out-of-bounds read of heap memory when parsing a malicious WebM/Matroska file. The memory is used as a pointer to an object instance, on which a vtable function call is made, which would result in code execution when combined with a suitable information leak.<span class="line"><!---->A vulnerability has been found in the libwebm library for WebM v1.9.0, which results in an out-of-bounds read of heap memory when parsing a malicious WebM/Matroska file. The memory is used as a pointer to an object instance, on which a vtable function call is made, which would result in code execution when combined with a suitable information leak.<!----></span><br><br>While libwebm is used by a number of other media/codec libraries, such as libaom and libvpx, there appear to be limited uses for this vulnerable code path. It is possible there are other users of this library which do exercise the vulnerable code path, but further research of media applications and libraries is required.<span class="line"><!---->While libwebm is used by a number of other media/codec libraries, such as libaom and libvpx, there appear to be limited uses for this vulnerable code path. It is possible there are other users of this library which do exercise the vulnerable code path, but further research of media applications and libraries is required.<!----></span><br><br>Context<span class="line"><!---->Context<!----></span><br>WebM is a container file format for audio/video codecs which is dervied from the Matroska (MKV) file format. The MKV format is binary stream of nested Tag-Length-Values which define various elements of the file and are split up into `Clusters` and `Segments`. Each `Segment` can contain a number of `Tracks` and each `Cluster` can contain a number of `Blocks` which hold the actual video/audio data for a `Track`. Specific points of interest within a `Track` can be recorded using `CuePoints`, which define a `TrackPosition` element which references the ID of the `Block` within the `Track` to seek to.Libwebm implements a number of classes to handle parsing of each supported element, of interest is the `CuePoint::TrackPosition` parser:<span class="line"><!---->WebM is a container file format for audio/video codecs which is dervied from the Matroska (MKV) file format. The MKV format is binary stream of nested Tag-Length-Values which define various elements of the file and are split up into `Clusters` and `Segments`. Each `Segment` can contain a number of `Tracks` and each `Cluster` can contain a number of `Blocks` which hold the actual video/audio data for a `Track`. Specific points of interest within a `Track` can be recorded using `CuePoints`, which define a `TrackPosition` element which references the ID of the `Block` within the `Track` to seek to.Libwebm implements a number of classes to handle parsing of each supported element, of interest is the `CuePoint::TrackPosition` parser:<!----></span><br><br>bool CuePoint::TrackPosition::Parse(IMkvReader* pReader, long long start_,<span class="line"><!---->bool CuePoint::TrackPosition::Parse(IMkvReader* pReader, long long start_,<!----></span><br>                                    long long size_) {<span class="line"><!---->                                    long long size_) {<!----></span><br>  const long long stop = start_ + size_;<span class="line"><!---->  const long long stop = start_ + size_;<!----></span><br>  long long pos = start_;<span class="line"><!---->  long long pos = start_;<!----></span><br>  m_track = -1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_track = -1;<!----></span><br>  m_pos = -1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_pos = -1;<!----></span><br>  m_block = 1;<span class="line"><!---->  m_block = 1;<!----></span><br><br>  // default<span class="line"><!---->  // default<!----></span><br>  while (pos < stop) {<span class="line"><!---->  while (pos &lt; stop) {<!----></span><br>    long len;<span class="line"><!---->    long len;<!----></span><br>    const long long id = ReadID(pReader, pos, len);<span class="line"><!---->    const long long id = ReadID(pReader, pos, len);<!----></span><br>    if ((id < 0) || ((pos + len) > stop)) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((id &lt; 0) || ((pos + len) &gt; stop)) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }      <span class="line"><!---->    }      <!----></span><br>    pos += len; // consume ID[1]<span class="line"><!---->    pos += len; // consume ID[1]<!----></span><br>    const long long size = ReadUInt(pReader, pos, len);<span class="line"><!---->    const long long size = ReadUInt(pReader, pos, len);<!----></span><br>    if ((size < 0) || ((pos + len) > stop)) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((size &lt; 0) || ((pos + len) &gt; stop)) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }<span class="line"><!---->    }<!----></span><br>    pos += len; // consume Size field<span class="line"><!---->    pos += len; // consume Size field<!----></span><br>    if ((pos + size) > stop) {<span class="line"><!---->    if ((pos + size) &gt; stop) {<!----></span><br>      return false;<span class="line"><!---->      return false;<!----></span><br>    }      <span class="line"><!---->    }      <!----></span><br>    if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueTrack)<span class="line"><!---->    if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueTrack)<!----></span><br>      m_track = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_track = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueClusterPosition)<span class="line"><!---->    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueClusterPosition)<!----></span><br>      m_pos = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_pos = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueBlockNumber)[2]<span class="line"><!---->    else if (id == libwebm::kMkvCueBlockNumber)[2]<!----></span><br>      m_block = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<span class="line"><!---->      m_block = UnserializeUInt(pReader, pos, size);<!----></span><br>    pos += size; // consume payload <span class="line"><!---->    pos += size; // consume payload <!----></span><br>  } //[3] <span class="line"><!---->  } //[3] <!----></span><br>  if ((m_pos < 0) || (m_track <= 0)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if ((m_pos &lt; 0) || (m_track &lt;= 0)) {<!----></span><br>    return false;<span class="line"><!---->    return false;<!----></span><br>  }    <span class="line"><!---->  }    <!----></span><br>  return true;<span class="line"><!---->  return true;<!----></span><br>}<span class="line"><!---->}<!----></span><br><br>The TLV for the `TrackPosition` section can container three values: the ID of the `Track`, the position within the `Cluster` for the `Track` and the Block ID within the `Cluster`. These values are also TLVs and the length for each is read at [1]. The MKV format supports reading numerical values up to 8 bytes in length and the function stores these in a `long long` where `-1` indicates an error. The ID for the `Block` is read at [2] but is excluded from the bounds check at [3], allowing an arbitrary 64-bit value to be read in to `m_block`.<span class="line"><!---->The TLV for the `TrackPosition` section can container three values: the ID of the `Track`, the position within the `Cluster` for the `Track` and the Block ID within the `Cluster`. These values are also TLVs and the length for each is read at [1]. The MKV format supports reading numerical values up to 8 bytes in length and the function stores these in a `long long` where `-1` indicates an error. The ID for the `Block` is read at [2] but is excluded from the bounds check at [3], allowing an arbitrary 64-bit value to be read in to `m_block`.<!----></span><br>This is an issue when users of libwebm attempt to fetch the Block for a `TrackPosition` via the `Cluster::GetEntry` API:<span class="line"><!---->This is an issue when users of libwebm attempt to fetch the Block for a `TrackPosition` via the `Cluster::GetEntry` API:<!----></span><br><br>const BlockEntry* Cluster::GetEntry(const CuePoint& cp,<span class="line"><!---->const BlockEntry* Cluster::GetEntry(const CuePoint&amp; cp,<!----></span><br>                                    const CuePoint::TrackPosition& tp) const {<span class="line"><!---->                                    const CuePoint::TrackPosition&amp; tp) const {<!----></span><br>  const long long tc = cp.GetTimeCode(); //[4] <span class="line"><!---->  const long long tc = cp.GetTimeCode(); //[4] <!----></span><br>  if (tp.m_block < 0) { //[5]   <span class="line"><!---->  if (tp.m_block &lt; 0) { //[5]   <!----></span><br>    const long block = static_cast<long>(tp.m_block);<span class="line"><!---->    const long block = static_cast&lt;long&gt;(tp.m_block);<!----></span><br>    const long index = block - 1; //[6]<span class="line"><!---->    const long index = block - 1; //[6]<!----></span><br>    while (index >= m_entries_count) {<span class="line"><!---->    while (index &gt;= m_entries_count) {<!----></span><br>      long long pos;<span class="line"><!---->      long long pos;<!----></span><br>      long len;<span class="line"><!---->      long len;<!----></span><br>      const long status = Parse(pos, len);        <span class="line"><!---->      const long status = Parse(pos, len);        <!----></span><br>      if (status < 0)  <span class="line"><!---->      if (status &lt; 0)  <!----></span><br>        // TODO: can this happen?          <span class="line"><!---->        // TODO: can this happen?          <!----></span><br>        return NULL;        <span class="line"><!---->        return NULL;        <!----></span><br>      if (status > 0) <span class="line"><!---->      if (status &gt; 0) <!----></span><br>        // nothing remains to be parsed          <span class="line"><!---->        // nothing remains to be parsed          <!----></span><br>        return NULL;<span class="line"><!---->        return NULL;<!----></span><br>      } //[7]   <span class="line"><!---->      } //[7]   <!----></span><br>      const BlockEntry* const pEntry = m_entries[index]; //[8]   <span class="line"><!---->      const BlockEntry* const pEntry = m_entries[index]; //[8]   <!----></span><br>      const Block* const pBlock = pEntry->GetBlock();        <span class="line"><!---->      const Block* const pBlock = pEntry-&gt;GetBlock();        <!----></span><br>      if ((pBlock->GetTrackNumber() == tp.m_track) &&<span class="line"><!---->      if ((pBlock-&gt;GetTrackNumber() == tp.m_track) &amp;&amp;<!----></span><br>          (pBlock->GetTimeCode(this) == tc)) {<span class="line"><!---->          (pBlock-&gt;GetTimeCode(this) == tc)) {<!----></span><br>        return pEntry;      <span class="line"><!---->        return pEntry;      <!----></span><br>      }    <span class="line"><!---->      }    <!----></span><br>    }    <span class="line"><!---->    }    <!----></span><br>    // ...<span class="line"><!---->    // ...<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  At [4] a check is made that the 64-bit `long long` block ID in `m_block` is greater than zero, which is then downcast to a 32-bit `long` at [5]. As an arbitrary 64-bit value can be read in from the TLV, a positive 64-bit value can be truncated to a negative 32-bit value and stored in the `block` variable. As `block` is now negative, the loop at [6] can be skipped. At [7] the negative 32-bit value is then used as an index into the `m_entries` array of `BlockEntry`'s which will read out-of-bounds, resulting in an invalid `BlockEntry*`. At [8] this will result in a vtable being read from the invalid pointer and a call made to one of its functions.<span class="line"><!---->  At [4] a check is made that the 64-bit `long long` block ID in `m_block` is greater than zero, which is then downcast to a 32-bit `long` at [5]. As an arbitrary 64-bit value can be read in from the TLV, a positive 64-bit value can be truncated to a negative 32-bit value and stored in the `block` variable. As `block` is now negative, the loop at [6] can be skipped. At [7] the negative 32-bit value is then used as an index into the `m_entries` array of `BlockEntry`'s which will read out-of-bounds, resulting in an invalid `BlockEntry*`. At [8] this will result in a vtable being read from the invalid pointer and a call made to one of its functions.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  Exploitation<span class="line"><!---->  Exploitation<!----></span><br>  It is likely that a separate information leak would be required to exploit this vulnerability. With an information leak it should be possible to groom the heap during file parsing such that the invalid `BlockEntry*` points at user-controllable memory containing a fake vtable in order to gain initial RCE. As MKV `Cluster`'s can contain `Block`'s with a relatively arbitrary size containing arbitrary binary data, they would make a useful primitive for the heap groom. The Block ID can be an arbitrary negative 32-bit value as well, which allows for a lot of flexibility in positioning memory to use as the fake `BlockEntry`.<span class="line"><!---->  It is likely that a separate information leak would be required to exploit this vulnerability. With an information leak it should be possible to groom the heap during file parsing such that the invalid `BlockEntry*` points at user-controllable memory containing a fake vtable in order to gain initial RCE. As MKV `Cluster`'s can contain `Block`'s with a relatively arbitrary size containing arbitrary binary data, they would make a useful primitive for the heap groom. The Block ID can be an arbitrary negative 32-bit value as well, which allows for a lot of flexibility in positioning memory to use as the fake `BlockEntry`.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>  A C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path is included with this report.<span class="line"><!---->  A C++ POC for exercising the vulnerable code path It's specific to the demuxer, which Chrome does not use. The library was fixed and copies in libvpx, libaom and Android were updated. I had some follow up questions for the reporter in that bug which were never answered.<span class="line"><!---->. It's specific to the demuxer, which Chrome does not use.         Description #1 by secur...@ncsc.gov.uk (Feb 20, 2023)
